answers: The grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy is thirty days (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf). This means that after the premium due date, there is a specified period of thirty days during which the premium payment can be made to renew or continue the policy without loss of continuity benefits.

The waiting period for pre-existing diseases (PED) to be covered is 36 months of continuous coverage after the date of inception of the first policy with the insurance company (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf).

Yes, the policy does cover maternity expenses. Maternity expenses include medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during hospitalization) except ectopic pregnancy, as well as expenses towards miscarriage (unless due to an accident) and lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the policy period (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf).

The waiting period for cataract surgery is 24 months (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf). This means that individuals covered under the policy will have to wait for 24 months before being eligible for cataract surgery coverage.

The medical expenses for an organ donor are not explicitly mentioned as covered under the Arogya Sanjeevani Policy. The policy specifies coverage for hospitalization expenses for the insured person (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf). Since there is no specific mention of coverage for organ donors in the provided documents, it is safe to say that the policy does not cover medical expenses for organ donors.
The No Claim Discount (NCD) offered in this policy is not explicitly mentioned in the provided documents.

The documents provided do not directly mention the benefits of preventive health check-ups. Therefore, based on the information available, there is no specific information to support the benefits of preventive health check-ups in the context of the Arogya Sanjeevani Policy. (No specific document referenced)

The policy defines a 'Hospital' as any institution established for in-patient care and day care treatment of disease/injuries, which has been registered as a hospital with the local authorities under the Clinical Establishments (Registration and Regulation) Act, 2010 or complies with specific criteria such as having qualified nursing staff, a minimum number of inpatient beds, qualified medical practitioners, a fully equipped operation theatre, and maintaining daily records of patients (Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf).

The extent of coverage for AYUSH treatments includes medical and/or hospitalization treatments given under Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Sidha, and Homeopathy systems of medicines in any AYUSH Hospital during each Policy Period up to the limit of the sum insured as specified in the policy schedule (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf). This means that AYUSH treatments are covered up to the specified sum insured in any AYUSH Hospital.

Yes, there are sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges for Plan A. The sublimit for room rent is up to 2% of the Sum Insured subject to a maximum of Rs. 5,000 per day, and the sublimit for ICU charges is up to 5% of the Sum Insured subject to a maximum of Rs. 10,000 per day (Document: Arogya_Sanjeevani_Policy.pdf). These sub-limits indicate the maximum amount that can be claimed for room rent and ICU charges under Plan A.
